message_1:
Suppose two best friends go hunting in the forest. They both have to decide whether to hunt stag or hare. If both hunt stag, they can catch a large animal and get a payoff of 4 units each. However, if one hunts stag and the other hunts hare, the one who hunts hare can still catch a small animal and get a payoff of 2 units while the one who hunts stag receives no payoff. If both hunt hare, they can each catch a small animal and get a payoff of 1 unit each.

What is the Nash equilibrium of this stag hunt game?
message_2:
In the stag hunt game, there are two Nash equilibria:

1. Both players choose to hunt stag (Stag, Stag): In this case, both players receive a payoff of 4 units each. If either player were to switch to hunting hare, their payoff would decrease to 2 units, so neither player has an incentive to change their strategy.

2. Both players choose to hunt hare (Hare, Hare): In this case, both players receive a payoff of 1 unit each. If either player were to switch to hunting stag, their payoff would decrease to 0 units, so neither player has an incentive to change their strategy.

Thus, the Nash equilibria of the stag hunt game are (Stag, Stag) and (Hare, Hare).
